Born in the USA is a fast and exciting rock album, but its lyrics are deep and emotional. The catchy rock songs tell stories about the difficult side of the American dream. Many songs talk about the struggles of everyday people and the anger they feel when life does not give them success or happiness. For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town remembering their youth when they felt full of hope, while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. It’s easy to see that the artist is inspired by real people he knew and the life he could have had if he hadn’t become famous. This album shows the amazing talent of the Boss.

Lewis wants to increase the number of marine protected areas in the world from 3 percent to 10 percent. He believes this can help fix the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, pollution, and littering. During his trips, Lewis has seen this environmental damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs that have lost their color because of warmer water and has seen lifeless areas in the shallow waters of the Red Sea filled with plastic. Pugh thinks that nature can heal if we give it a chance, but time is running out. If we don’t start taking care of our seas, we might face a big problem soon.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell great stories. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times. Terrie grew up in a neighborhood in Glasgow with a lot of crime. There, she learned to stay quiet, avoid trouble, and even how to open car doors with a knife. Fortunately, she only used these skills for her writing. Now, she is not so quiet anymore and appears on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences across the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is it impossible to make progress? In "Enlightenment Now," Steven Pinker examines human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. Pinker believes the real problem is that the values of reason and science from the Enlightenment are being attacked. When people focus on tribalism, hopelessness, and distrust, we risk harming important institutions like democracy and global cooperation.

In older horror films, when the main characters were in trouble, it was hard or impossible for them to call for help or the police. Now, with mobile phones, this seems less believable. So, how do filmmakers keep the suspense? They use no phone coverage! If you are a hero in a horror movie, it’s very likely that at a crucial moment, when you really need to call for help, you won’t have any signal. Or your phone battery will die just as you try to make the call. Or both will happen.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their most profitable product, the Gros Michel banana, also called Big Mike. Now, the same thing is happening to its replacement, the Cavendish banana. The Gros Michel banana was popular because it was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. United Fruit, the main banana grower and exporter in South America at that time, produced bananas in a very efficient way. They cloned shoots from the plants instead of growing them from seeds and planted them closely together in fields.

Most spiders have venom that helps them catch their prey, not to attack humans. Only 25 spider species can harm people, and while their bites can hurt, they are usually not deadly. For example, the Sydney funnel-web spider in Australia has not caused any deaths since the anti-venom was created in 1981. However, be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can release irritating hairs that can get stuck in the skin or eyes of anyone who bothers them.

This horror film idea was very popular in the late 20th century. It begins with a group of teenagers having fun, and it ends with everyone dead except for one girl. At first, the girl is usually innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes the strongest and smartest person. The last girl almost always wins in the end.

To understand where our ability to use complex language comes from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. It's not just about brain size; we also need to consider what other functions our brains have and how they developed over time. There are not many physical clues to help us; the tools left by our ancestors do not show us what kind of speech they could make. However, we can see changes in the mouth, throat, and tongue of early humans. About 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.

Society, not nature, tells us that girls should like arts and humanities, while boys should focus on maths and physics. There are also not enough positive female role models in science jobs for young people to see. Cartoons and stories often show scientists, inventors, or astronauts as men. Many people wrongly think that scientists are nerdy, have bad social skills, or work alone and away from others. These stereotypes from the media can make girls feel like they do not belong in science and see it as an unattractive career. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, it would help them feel more confident and included in these subjects.

The Scallion is a weekly newspaper that is given out for free in faculty buildings, reaching about 10,000 students. It is created by students. A survey shows that university students and staff really appreciate the newspaper for entertainment, culture, and work experience. Printing the newspapers costs a lot of money. Also, some students find it hard to get a copy because they have to go to the university to pick one up. Another problem is that many copies end up as litter on campus.

At Girox Foods, we have an annual employee turnover of about 12 percent. This may not seem high, but the industry average is 7 percent. The main goal of this report is to look into why employees are engaged at our company and to give suggestions on how to improve their experience at work and keep them longer.

What the speaker said felt very true to me. I really believe that the more connected we are, the more alone we can feel. This is not a big problem for my generation, as we have lived without technology for a long time. We know how to be alone and understand that it’s okay to be alone. But for those under 20, it’s different. They are so busy talking online that they don’t know what it feels like to be alone and might not learn to enjoy their own company. Also, they are learning to talk through messages that can be changed, instead of learning how to have real conversations with people face to face.

Don't always give negative feedback after positive feedback. If you always mix them together, people might not value the positive comments. Make sure to give positive feedback on its own sometimes, and try not to add criticism right after.
